50:59 Caption: What an entertaining encounter between these two teams. Let's hope there will more of the same in their other games. The home team had more of the game. The strategy of the home side was to control the pace of the match with possession style football. Whereas the strategy of the away side was a bit risky and reliant on solid defending to dispossess the opponent and break fast.
    

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
On a brisk afternoon at Stamford Bridge, Chelsea and West Ham United clashed in what turned out to be a thrilling Premier League encounter that finished 2-2. Both teams were eager to secure all three points, and their determination was evident from the very first whistle.

The first half kicked off with Chelsea immediately asserting their dominance, launching an early attack. However, this initial burst of energy quickly dissipated into a series of interruptions, with the ball going out of play multiple times and West Ham trying to find their rhythm. At just 26 seconds in, the first stoppage for a throw-in by West Ham occurred, setting a precedent for a number of halts in the flow of the game. 

West Ham showed early signs of struggle with an offside decision against them in the first minute. As the match progressed, Chelsea's defensive prowess was tested on several occasions. West Ham managed to fire a shot off-target at the fourth minute, an indication of their attacking intent. Yet Chelsea cleared their lines well, staving off the early pressure from their visitors.

In the ninth minute, Chelsea carved out their first significant chance with a shot on target, but West Ham's Adrian was equal to the task. Enner Valencia of West Ham showcased some individual brilliance in the tenth minute but was unable to convert it into a meaningful opportunity as he ran into a robust Chelsea defense.

West Ham's primary creator, Dimitri Payet, spearheaded several set-piece opportunities but found little success initially. His corner in the tenth minute found Winston Reid, whose header lacked power and was comfortably saved by the Chelsea goalkeeper. The match then took a more combative turn, with Branislav Ivanovic receiving the first booking of the day in the 15th minute after a rash challenge.

West Ham's persistence paid off in the 16th minute when Manuel Lanzini demonstrated his striking prowess. Controlling the ball just outside the penalty area, Lanzini unleashed a thunderous shot into the roof of the net, leaving no chance for the Chelsea keeper. This brilliant strike by Lanzini gave West Ham a 1-0 lead.

Chelsea, refusing to be disheartened, resumed their offensive quest with renewed vigor. Consistently pressing high up the pitch, they sought to exploit any gaps in West Ham's backline. West Ham, on the other hand, looked dangerous on the counter, emphasizing their lethal ability to transition from defense to attack.

As the match approached the half-hour mark, Chelsea earned several corners, though West Ham's defense remained resilient. Chelsea's attempts included significant contributions from Willian, whose corners and free kicks consistently threatened but fell just short of breaking through. Notably, a long-range free kick by Willian in the 40th minute narrowly missed the target, grazing past the left post.

West Ham had a moment of promise just before halftime when Chelsea's John Obi Mikel conceded a foul leading to a yellow card. Yet their ensuing direct free-kick failed to cause much trouble. As the first half neared its conclusion, Chelsea mounted one final promising attack. In stoppage time, Chelsea's perseverance was rewarded. Cesc Fabregas delivered a stunning free-kick in the 48th minute, bending the ball into the top left corner. This breathtaking strike leveled the score at 1-1 and injected life into the home fans.

The referee's whistle brought an end to the first half with both teams heading into the dressing rooms locked at one goal apiece. The performance in the first half set the stage for an electrifying second segment of the game where more thrilling moments were to unfold.

The second half began with a substitution from Chelsea, bringing on Pedro in hopes of adding more firepower. West Ham immediately got back into the action with a shot off-target in the early minutes. Shortly after that, Diafra Sakho found himself caught offside. Chaos continued with Chelsea showing intent to press forward and control the game while West Ham relied on quick breaks to unsettle the Blues.

Chelsea’s persistent attacks bore fruits frequently, but the crucial finishing touch eluded them on several occasions. One notable effort came from Oscar after a beautiful delivery from Branislav Ivanovic, only to see his shot miss the target by a whisker.

West Ham's response was equally promising. Cheikhou Kouyate applied forceful but fair tackles, disrupting Chelsea's momentum but at the cost of a few fouls which culminated in some free-kick opportunities for the hosts. An indirect free-kick for Chelsea saw John Terry leap high to head the ball, but his effort was thwarted by an agile Adrian.

Another bout of substitutions punctuated the narrative of the second half. West Ham brought on Andy Carroll for Diafra Sakho at the 59th minute, hoping to capitalize on Carroll's physical presence and aerial prowess. Their tactics paid off spectacularly. Minutes after his introduction, Carroll received a precise pass inside the box and found the bottom left corner with an emphatic effort, putting West Ham ahead 2-1 in the 62nd minute.

Chelsea refused to relent. Loic Remy made way for Bertrand Traore, as Guus Hiddink sought more attacking options. Traore’s introduction added pace and fresh legs for the final push. The match turned more physical as West Ham's Cheikhou Kouyate and Michail Antonio were booked for their aggressive play.

A controversial penalty decision in the 86th minute turned the tide. Michail Antonio's clumsy foul inside the penalty box did not escape the referee's attention. The ensuing penalty was calmly converted by Cesc Fabregas, who shot into the bottom right corner, leveling the score once again at 2-2. This penalty conversion was crucial and provided the final dramatic twist to the narrative of the game.

Towards the end, further offensive endeavors from Chelsea saw Ruben Loftus-Cheek making a significant impact. The game continued to be fiercely contested with both sides exchanging shots off target. Defensive clearances and midfield battles kept everyone on edge until the final whistle.

Ultimately, the game concluded in a 2-2 draw, epitomizing the very essence of Premier League drama, filled with stunning goals, tactical battles, controversial decisions, and relentless spirits. The home team managed to hold the edge in terms of possession and control, attempting to steer the pace of play with their passing maneuvers. In contrast, West Ham's strategy of robust defending coupled with sharp counter-attacks nearly clinched an away victory.

The fans at Stamford Bridge left thoroughly entertained by an engaging spectacle, with each side showing grit and determination. Chelsea came close to capitalizing fully on their home advantage with their attacking prowess, while West Ham's resilience shone through, earning them a well-fought point. As the season progresses, both teams have shown they possess the fighting spirit and quality to challenge their opponents, making every game count.
